ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of cell biology, which will be helpful in future MCDB courses

Comprehensive coverage of the most important cellular processes - DNA and the nucleus, membranes, organelles and trafficking, signaling, cell adhesion, cytoskeleton and motility, and the cell cycle. Covered 45/46 chapters in the textbook (only skipped meiosis), so you know what you're getting into.
I gained a pretty in-depth view of cell biology, especially in regards to signaling pathways and intracellular mechanisms.
Basics of cell biology. Lots of material, but in a digestible fashion
I got a great overview of many large cell biology topics with a particular focus on intracellular transport and organizational systems.

The course covered an incredible amount of information regarding cell biology. I feel like I have a much deeper understanding of many complex processes from a molecular level, as well as a better ability to predict what will go wrong when certain steps are interrupted. I also improved my ability to design experiments to study different processes and learned about many experimental techniques.
More in depth material on cell processes, good involved content on biology
Basic mechanisms of cellular organization, signaling pathways, and the cell cycle.
I learned so much about biology at a cellular level. It was so interesting, much better than the bio intro sequence. I highly recommend this course.
I learned how cells function  sensing their environments, growing, dying, moving by using different pathways, receptors, and by coupling these functions to chemical energy.
We covered the almost all the topics of cell bio and went in depth to many concepts.

So much about experimental techniques, model organisms, the nucleus, transcription/translation, the secretory pathway, pumps/carriers/channels, signaling, extracellular membrane, actin/microtubules, cell cycle, and more
Biological vocabulary and a general overview on the main themes of cell biology

I learned about basic cell biology, including cellular processes with each organelle. We also covered signal pathways, experimental techniques, cytoskeleton, and the cell cycle. I developed skills to thinking about experimental design to test if a specific phenomena occurred. This course really filled in a lot of my gaps in knowledge for biology and provided a solid foundation.
A greater foray into the world of cell biology, as well as the experimental basis.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: very organized teaching team! The amount of resources available was also great

Weaknesses: THis class felt like it would never end. The weekly quizzes were relentless -- being able to drop 3 quiz grades was so helpful

I was incredibly grateful that this course provided study guides/review sheets for each lecture which helped me review key topics. These guides also had review questions that were very useful in making sure I understood the concepts at hand. One thing that could be improved would be that sometimes for quizzes, I would lose a point on something very technical (such as not stating explicitly that ATP hydolysis was the source of energy even though the question may have already suggested that it was so).

This class goes at a very fast pace and is not designed for students who may be dealing with other things or courses. There is not much accommodation for students and there is far too much material and too much detail you must pay attention, as they never specify what information is important for quizzes or tests.

Lecturing was high quality. Sometimes quizzes were stressful. Having weekly quizzes were important to keep you on top of material. I do kind of wish there was maybe some sort of homework or some other assignment we could do

I thought this class was extremely interesting and we learned a lot but I was overwhelmed at times. I wish we spent more time connecting the different topics and identifying which components of a complex system were actually important to memorize. Trying to synthesize all of the information for the final was very difficult and I would have found it almost impossible to do had the quizzes and exams been closed note.

The strength is definitely the weekly quizzes. This is the only way to manageably test you on the incredible amount of content you are faced with in the course. Unfortunately, the grading for the quizzes was very unpredictable, and took a sharp downward turn later in the semester. On the last couple of quizzes, it got very challenging to determine what, exactly, the graders were looking for and how much detail to go into in the limited time available. Also, the final exam at the end of the course completely undid the awesome quiz format. It is completely impractical to be tested on all of the course content at once and it was ridiculous that we couldn't go back to revise our answers, despite that being a Yale final exam requirement.

The course is fast paced, but it is clear the professors want to provide an engaging learning environment. They are very good about posting slides and their study guides in advance. The fact that lectures were recorded this semester was also incredibly helpful; I was able to rewatch several before the final exam. The weekly quizzes are also very fair, and I appreciated how they ensured I stayed engaged with the course. One of my best experiences in a STEM course as Yale. The final exam was well-written, and I appreciated how the professors made it challenging in spite of it being open note.

The lecturers were all passionate and the course material was relatively interesting. Sometimes it was quite fast paced and a lot of reading was requires. The weekly quiz format was a great way to understand the material and familiarise oneself with the exam layout.
It was extremely well organized and structured to facilitate learning. The material was very fascinating and engaging, with many applications in the real world.

Strengths: Extremely comprehensive
Weaknesses: Quick paced
The grading for quizzes was slightly nitpicky, but they really helped when it comes to staying on top of the material. The teachers are amazing and the textbook is very straightforward and helpful.

Great professors and TFs. The handouts were very helpful. Weekly quizzes were also helpful for keeping me on top of material. A weakness would be that the material was a bit uneven  some weeks were harder and more packed than others. Reallocating time a bit would be helpful, even if this meant some class periods we went over two units while for others we went through less than one.

This course is the best course I have ever taken at Yale. The organization is outstanding. You can really tell that the professors prioritized their students. Grades are entered extremely quick and professors put recording the lectures and uploading them immediately as a priority. There are fair opportunities to improve your grade. You learn so much about the cell and the emphasis on applying the knowledge as opposed to only memorization is very successful. TAKE THIS CLASS! Do not be dissuaded at all by how much the workload appears to be, this class will change your entire understanding of cell (and frankly, mol) biology. There are no weaknesses.

Strengths: I liked the quiz format 
Weakness: the pace was hard at times but I understand why it was necessary with the amount of information we had to cover
I believe that in person lectures will be better than online learning, but this lecture format still did well despite this weakness.

This course was such a great foundation to biology. The course was very organized, and I learned a lot of the details I needed to in order to apply them in the future to research. We talked about experimental design, which is going to help in the application of the material. The professors and TFs are very receptive to questions, and they make sure you have all the resources you need to succeed in the course, such as the study guides and the many practice questions. The study guides enhance understanding and help organization, and the discussion sections help to understand the questions since the material is very dense. My only suggestion for improvement of the course is to maybe have psets in addition to only the quizzes and the final. Exams were stressful, although the questions were always interesting and enhanced learning.
I think having the peer tutors record their review sessions for each quiz, or have it earlier in the week to accommodate other sections or scheduling conflicts would be nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I definitely think opening up the weekly quizzes to be open-note was helpful in reducing the stress. I guess the only to this would be that although the final was also open-note, because I didn't need to memorize a lot of the information it was harder at the end to pinpoint topics.

Were not nice to students during pandemic time. There were no accommodations or help from any of the professors. It is really disappointing because some of them seemed nice but the pressure put on students to know so much material really outweighed the good.
Lectures were good virtual. Open note quizzes and tests were helpful
The virtual lectures were fine, although I think more interactive elements would have made the hour and 15 minute lectures more enjoyable.
The recordings were very helpful for studying, and because the course had so much material, I found I stayed very engaged the entire time.
The accessibility of the lecture summaries was great, and the discussion sections really helped. The lecturers were also very understanding in working around international time zones.
Discussion section were helpful.
Recorded lectures were awesome and should be kept even in a regular school year. Discussion sections online should be kept.
Recording the lecture was a great idea. I often watched them back to understand the things i missed due to the pace.

The lectures, which were recorded, was tremendously helpful. I would often go back to the recorded lectures to fill in details that I had missed, and this greatly improved my understanding of the material. The occasional breakout rooms helped with engagement, and discussion sections were always very helpful and engaging as I got to interact with classmates.
I think this course had some of the best practices in terms of learning during the pandemic, but the peer tutors could have been a little better.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class gives you so much information but the teaching team is incredibly organized and does a great job with providing students resources to help study. The weekly quizzes are relentless and it's important to stay on top of the material week to week. Sometimes this class can feel overwhelming, but there are no "surprises" to this class or in the grading scheme and professors and TAs are consistent in grading and posting lectures/slides.

Yes, I'd recommend it to anyone interested in biology at virtually any level. There's plenty of overlap with other courses, but I thought MCDB 205 provided an excellent overview of how cells function as the basic unit of biology. It's not particularly easy (especially since it probably won't be open-note in future years like it was for the online version), and there's a ton of content; however, it's well organized so that attending lecture and reviewing the handouts should prepare you for the quizzes, with the textbook available to help with the finer details for the curious.

I would only recommend this course to other MCDB majors and pre-med students. In terms of workload and material covered, this course has definitely been one of my tougher courses. However, it is very clear that I learned a lot from it and I think overall, the material was very interesting to learn given that cell biology is also such a foundation topic to understand.
No. Unless you have a free schedule to spend all your time on this course, I advise otherwise.
Yes, if it's still open note!

I would recommend this class to anyone truly interested in the subject matter, it is not an easy MCDB core class but it is very informative. Only take if you feel comfortable setting aside a lot of time to study for the weekly quizzes which are 60% of your grade.

I'd recommend this as a MCDB core course. This is a decent intro course, and the sheer amount of content you learn is great (except for when you are tested on it all at the end in a crazy impractical format).

This course is a lot of work (definitely much more work when in-person and closed book), but it is worth it. I would not at all consider it an easy A, but it is well structured and the professors are all very knowledgeable and inspiring. I would recommend it only to students aware of these aspects beforehand.
Yes, it is a good bio course for those who need to take one for their major
Yes! I learned so much about basic mechanisms of cellular functioning and its applications to medicine and research.
Yes
Yes, this class is amazing and so interesting. You really have to engage with the material and study a lot but it is so worth it.
Yes! It covers so much general information that when you come out of it, you'll feel comfortable learning other higher level bio courses.
This is a must have course if you are biology major. The class does a great job introducing so many relevant concepts that will be useful to your upper level class and research.

This is the hardest course I have taken. The material is extensive. I would recommend this to people who ware really interested in cell bio, but not as one of the core MCDB classes. The workload is too intense.

This course is the best course I have ever taken at Yale. The organization is outstanding. You can really tell that the professors prioritized their students. Grades are entered extremely quick and professors put recording the lectures and uploading them immediately as a priority. There are fair opportunities to improve your grade. You learn so much about the cell and the emphasis on applying the knowledge as opposed to only memorization is very successful. TAKE THIS CLASS! Do not be dissuaded at all by how much the workload appears to be, this class will change your entire understanding of cell (and frankly, mol) biology.
Sure, this core class is probably a good foundation for higher level MCDB classes.  This is pretty well taught.
Yes if you are planning to major in MCDB. If not and you just want an overview of cell biology with less stress, I'd take a less intense course
If they are interested in biology, I would suggest this course.

I would definitely recommend this course. I have learned the most amount of biology from this course compared to others. The material is very applicable and will serve as a solid foundation for upper level classes and research. I felt supported to succeed even though the material was very dense and hard to get through sometimes. I loved the challenge from the amount of material and also the questions that were provided. The course filled in so many gaps in knowledge, and I feel like I understand more biology as a whole now.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, but that might be because I already enjoy cell biology. It very well organized if you enjoy the content, and it is structured in a way that you can succeed.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recommended weekly discussion section to go over pre-assigned review questions.
Live virtual discussion sections.
Section once a week with the TA
Live and recorded virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section.
Live virtual lecture with weekly discussion sections
recorded lecture plus once weekly virtual discussion
Weekly live section with smaller group and TF
in-person discussion section
Live virtual discussion
Virtual live discussion section
Discussion Section
We had live virtual lectures twice and a virtual discussion section per week. Live lectures were recorded.
